chunks.en: 35 years old, married with children, is there still a possibility of emigrating?
After looking into the policies for my child entering elementary school next year, I'm disheartened.
Originally, I planned to go back to my hometown for schooling, but now my wife wants to stay in Beijing. Currently in Beijing, unemployed.

The only way to break the deadlock is to find a job that can obtain a work permit, otherwise I can only return to my place of origin. I don't have much savings, no IELTS or Japanese proficiency, I don't know if there is any possibility of emigration?
If there is, please give me some advice. (I often feel guilty when I look at my wife and children, sorry for not giving them a better future.) I hope young people can see this and plan ahead.
My experience of emigrating to Japan with my wife: https://springwood.me/new-life-in-japan/
I emigrated to Singapore with my wife and two children at the age of 35. After nearly two years of hard work, I am now basically stable and preparing to apply for PR.
Although the mainstream on V2EX advises emigration, I'll take a contrarian view. Your conditions are too poor, you might as well go back to your hometown.
You don't know a foreign language, you won't find a good job if you emigrate.
Your wife and children are waiting for you to support them, are you going to let them take risks with you?
That's too irresponsible.
@ramirezyolis808 #41 Well, let me share some information I know and you can judge for yourself.
*Not accurate, the following are just my personal opinions.
1. The Japanese are very xenophobic, and it is generally difficult for Chinese people to reach senior technical positions in purely Japanese companies.

2. Japan favors seniority, and promotion requires many years of hard work, especially for those dispatched from overseas. In larger companies, it takes several years just to become a 'regular employee'.
3. Before the epidemic, the salary of a mid-level coder in Tokyo was about 1.5 times that of a major city in China, and the cost of living was also about 1.5-2 times.
But the Japanese exchange rate has fallen sharply in recent years.

@qingpei88800 Beijing Work Permit == Beijing Green Card, except for not being able to participate in the college entrance examination, it is considered the same as a Beijing resident in terms of buying a house, lottery for car license plates, and compulsory education.
@magic3584 It's not impossible to study outside of Beijing, that's how I came all the way.
Initially, I applied for the five certificates, and later I used the work permit to go to school.

If you don't want your child to be left behind or go to Tianjin to study, you can consider letting your child take the international route in elementary school (learn English well from an early age, and have a TOEFL score of around 115 in the third year of junior high school), so that you can go to the international department of a public high school (but it's very competitive, mainly because there are too many non-Beijing residents and too few places, if you have a work permit, it will be much better, 80,000-120,000 a year).
In addition to TOEFL, you also need to look at the high school entrance examination results.

I don't know which district you plan to send your child to school in, if possible, Haidian or Xicheng, at least these two districts have more enrollment quotas for the international departments of public high schools.

If you don't have a work permit, you can consider Renchao Branch in Chaoyang District (private, it seems to be 160,000 a year), you can take the 1+3 route in junior high school without participating in the high school entrance examination and go directly to the international department of high school.
However, the problem with going to the international department is that it requires a lot of money, at least for now, at least 500,000 for 3 years of high school.
Calculate 500,000 per year for studying abroad, and it is estimated that it will cost nearly 3 million to graduate from undergraduate.
@mesh The current birth rate means these are not issues anymore, don't panic.
It's better to make money in China.
Unless you are a skilled technical professional headhunted by a high-paying foreign company.
Second-tier cities are pretty good.
You don't have an advantage studying in the capital.
Because their policies change every year.
You might catch up this year, but you won't catch up in 6 years.
In essence, it's a game where the referee changes the rules at any time, and you, as an athlete, always have to readjust your direction after each change, and you'll never catch up.
500,000-1,000,000 in savings is enough for the next 10 years.
Just teach the children yourself.
You can't learn anything at school.

Except for all kinds of comparisons and resource investments, such as the rich competing for equestrianism, golf, international departments, and the ordinary competing for the college entrance examination, it's actually useless.
In essence, you can't predict the future.
If you really want to teach, teach them how to survive in change.
The future is dynamically developing, you can't know the standard answer now to tell your child.
But one thing I'm sure of.
That is, 500,000-1,000,000 is really enough.
Because prices will be very cheap in the future.
If you don't believe me, look at pork prices.

chunks.en: Furthermore, as parents, you can't give up learning about history and finance, because no university in the world teaches these two subjects. If you don't teach your children, they won't learn them anywhere, unless they have strong self-learning abilities and are strong after being hurt by society, then they can learn in practice, otherwise, early education is better / Finance History Game Theory Statistics Biology Psychology Simple data analysis Human-computer communication Relationships with the opposite gender How to deal with disagreements and conflicts Physical health It's enough to learn these subjects well.
Because these can survive economic cycles.
Second tier is not bad.
If you emigrate rashly, you will be scammed to death by agents.
Base yourself in a second-tier city and then look for business trip opportunities to go out for inspections. Is this a lower risk way to emigrate?

chunks.en: Also, unless you don't need to take care of both parents, otherwise if you emigrate, they will be useless, and it will be miserable if no one takes care of them when they are old, and you will feel guilty at that time.

/'Unfortunately, we are a place with very poor welfare, and 3 generations of families are locked together. Very few people have the ability to escape. It all requires strong economic strength to do it.
For more traditional people, the resistance to emigrating mostly comes from their parents' retirement...
35 years old, with wife and children, unemployed in Beijing, not much savings, no IELTS and no Japanese level, the buffs are fully stacked, so don't even think about emigrating.

@wxw752 Don't mention it, I'm from Henan, eastern Henan, I took the college entrance examination in 2012. When we were in junior high and high school, the school got up at 4:30 in the morning and got out of self-study at 9:30 in the evening, and finally only about 20% were admitted to undergraduate ... complaining about injustice is useless.

Looking at the current description, I guess the poster's savings may not be abundant. If there is enough money for a family of three to live abroad for a year or two, you can consider applying for elementary school in Canada, and then the couple can go there to accompany the child...

Then use a year's buffer to study how to survive, your wife can apply to school, and you can get a work visa or something... Check it out, a friend of mine emigrated with his whole family like this last year (it can only be considered pre-emigration)
Bro, after reading the introduction, I feel like you don't want to emigrate, but you want to escape...
I have a friend who emigrated to Australia with his wife and two children when he was almost 40... It's just a matter of determination.
It's like immigrating for the sake of the child's schooling in the same country, haha.
You really can't learn anything at school now.

As long as a high school student has a high degree of self-awareness and strong self-learning ability, they can go out to start a business in high school, suspend school, and the family will leave enough money for him to continue studying if the business fails.
The real geniuses are already awesome in high school, even if they go to college, they are self-taught, and they really can't learn anything at college.
Look at the textbooks in college, what year were they written? Can they keep up with the development of the times?
Three months in society is more than a year in college.
There are only 2 paths. If they enter the system in the future, they must get a high degree.
If they are outside the system in the future, they can learn economics, history, finance, communication, psychology, and game theory to survive outside the system.
Society is dynamically changing, and you must survive in change.
If the couple manages their retirement money well, the children will be very grateful.

Unlike my family, who are always being scammed, I have to keep filling the hole with their pension money. My family doesn't follow the times and learn, so they like to believe in scammers, it's unspeakable pain.
It's a self-study era.
If you don't believe me, look at your child's textbook, you'll see that you can't learn anything.
4 ideology classes a week.
It is knowledge that changes fate, not education.
And, knowledge is dynamically changing.
To be honest, if you are not doing well in China, you will probably do worse if you go out, how can you manage if you can't even speak the language?
Those who post that they are doing well are either fully buffed or one in a million.
With that spirit, it's better to stay in China, at least you can speak and understand Chinese.
@xixibb That's not true, sit down.
I'm also 35, located in Australia.
I'm pretty confident in my technology.
But I haven't changed jobs for 8 years, so my income in China hasn't even reached the median among programmers.
My income directly quintupled after coming here.
5 times.
There is no PUA here, and the mental stress is also small.
I live like a person and can be respected.
There is no concept of expiration of annual leave. If you accumulate too much, you are forced to rest.
Overtime, doesn't exist.

Sometimes I want to finish things early and secretly work overtime, but I have to wait until the next day to commit, otherwise I might be cared aboutğŸ˜‚I also came here largely because of the education of the next generation, to break the cycle of raising sheep, selling sheep, and marrying a wife.
@kevin1452 #155 Does the landing experience refer to after landing?
In terms of life, it basically feels the same as in Shenzhen. 80% are Chinese, and the taste of food is more Fujianese, and there are fewer Cantonese tastes.

Rent has been at its peak in the past two years, doubling compared to the previous two years, and it won't fall anytime soon, so you can only grit your teeth and hold on, or settle for second best and rent some places with less favorable conditions.

It is more troublesome for children to go to school. If they are over six years old, they cannot directly attend public schools here, they can only study in international schools first, until they pass the entrance examination here before they can enroll.
After working for a few years, I emigrated back to my hometown... The cost of renting in first-tier cities is too high...
